posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91396769
I use both Scoop and winget. All my portable apps are from Scoop and the ones with installer are from winget.
>>Chocolatey
No one who has used it and winget, can say its better with a straight face.
>Outdated Packages
Once a package is uploaded to Chocolatey you rely on the maintainers whims for updates. You can't just make a github PR.
>Paywall
Chocolatey has certain features locked behind a paywall.
>Shitty Manifest
Unlike Winget and scoop, the nuget manifests of chocolatey are a mess.
>https://medium.com/@keivan/why-chocolatey-is-broken-beyond-any-hope-d1a4e33b3d23
>>Scoop
Good for portable apps only. I don't know why the nonportable bucket is an official bucket.
>https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Scoop/issues/3691
>https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Scoop/issues/2651
>https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Scoop/issues/3736
The moment you install something like IrfanView from Scoop and its added to "Programs and Features", Scoop can't completely control or manage it. You can now update the app from its built-in updater, but scoop still thinks you never updated it. Similarly uninstalling it from "Programs and Features" does not uninstall it from Scoop. The non-portable bucket and anything that registers itself to "Programs and Features" should be allowed on official buckets.
>>Winget
Winget can't install portable apps, when so many apps like everything in Scoop's main bucket are portable. In winget an app must either be packaged with an installer(inno, msix, msi) or be in the Microsoft Store. Use Scoop for portable apps and nerd-fonts.
Every app in "Programs and Features" is registered to RegEdit with a ProductCode. Uninstalling it through the msiexec command with the ProductCode and silent argument is just the CLI version pf clicking uninstall on "Programs and Features". winget list will just list all registered win32 and uwp apps.
Basically if you have installed vlc manually, winget can detect the version you have and will download the latest version.

posts.com:
>>91396203
>If I connect 3-pin fans to a fan controller (eg Lian Li Uni Hub) does that allow me to control them as if they were 4-pin fans?
No. You'd have to use the 3-pin pump port, if anything.

3-pin fan speed is controlled by lowering the source voltage down from 5V. A 4-pin fan controller can't do that, only 5V all the time, and varies the speed using a signal on the 4th pin instead. So the driver circuit is completely different.

posts.name: Self-Hosted AI General - Voice Synthesis
posts.com:
Read the pic on 11 labs approach.
We need to reverse engineer it and compare it to tortoise stack (see below) to suggest improvements. Check out the Tortoise forks below.

Free ML courses
https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/best-machine-learning-courses/
Other TTS models and AI TTS Overview and videos
https://pastebin.com/VcREHHWT

>Tortoise TTS stack: Learn what it does. Suggest improvements. Compare it to 11 labs.
1) Autoregressive transformer stack predicts discrete speech "tokens" given a text prompt. (Like DALLE using GPT but with speech)
2) CLIP model judges autoregressive transformer outputs against the text ranking the most probable.
3) Speech tokens are decoded into a low-quality MEL spectrogram using a VQVAE.
4) UNet diffusion model decodes VQVAE output into raw audio wav file using openAI ImprovedDiffusion.
>Tortoise is basically OpenAI's DALLE, applied to speech data.

>What can you do: Look for code improvements in these forks, report back
https://github.com/neonbjb/tortoise-tts/network/members

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91389997
https://ml.berkeley.edu/blog/posts/vq-vae/
https://desuarchive.org/g/thread/90222205/
gans vs vq-vae vs diffusion

>GANs
Were notoriously hard to train correctly, other than that they suffered heavily from mode chasing and were still subject to mode collapse
>VAEs
Severely subject to mode collapse, nearly impossible to balance capacity for modeling vs distributing. Unlike GANs, you couldn't mess with the parameters well enough to get them to work, it was more one or zero.
>Diffusions
Are basically a flattened version of highly deeply hierarchical VAEs (in the scoring model formulation, which is the more popular one). It has a nice analytical form that allows training in one shot, effectively by selecting which of the levels of the VAE hierarchy you want, and calculating the pre and post of the transformation in one step.
Style transfer is not a model but rather an application. Style transfer was done with GANs or with VAEs or autoregressive models like PixelCNN or PixelRNN.

Also, VAE variants like soft-infoVAE work about as well as diffusions in theory, but again suffer from finicky to balance hyperparameters (though the advantage is that they're crazy faster at inference time). VQ-VAEs can also work about as well, but I haven't seen this to be true in my experiments so either it's also very hard to balance or it only works in limited datasets (or not at all).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91390241
Check the previous thread, transcribing audio is not necessary. You can do it if you want but you don't have to. see
>https://github.com/neonbjb/tortoise-tts/discussions/264
No pre-trained text encoders were used with Tortoise. I experimented with this briefly but found it to be detrimental. This makes sense because TTS systems care more about the phonetic interpretation of each text character than the deeper meaning behind the words in a sentence.
It would probably be beneficial to condition a model like Tortoise on both the character level embeddings and the output of, for example, T5. There's been some success with using this idea in research for txt2im models lately that shows it allows these types of models to spell better.

>>91407818
Swarm Diffusion: Decentralized SD Model Training
>Train Stable Diffusion models across the internet with multiple peers
>By leveraging the power of multiple computers as peers, this project enables the training of machine learning models across the internet with high efficiency and fault-tolerance. The distributed training is facilitated by a DHT (Distributed Hash Table) which ensures that all peers are able to connect and share their training data. The resulting model is then averaged across all peers, ensuring that the final model is highly accurate and reliable. This decentralized approach allows for efficient and scalable model training without the need for a master node.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91407818
This gives you an idea of how they swarm training
1. Dataset
Currently code expect dataset to be in form of image jpg,jpeg,webp,png and accompanying json file that contains tags i.e danbooru dataset. Currently it's hardcoded and will be used as example one for that guide.
Sqlite db is stored in repo as index of files, and files served from linode bucket in pairs, there is check in code to discard non paired images. During training, both image and json are fetched, and from json extracted only description tags and saved as txt file alongside image in workplace directory.
2. Mother node
Currently it expects to have GPU and will be part of the swarm. For distributed training you also need configuration in next step.
3. Relay mode
Next step is to set up relay configuration in UI, that will allow your node to serve config endpoint to peers - from wich they will be able to grab config, for that purprose I.E port are used. So if you behind NAT it makes sense to portforward port 80 to your internal I.E port, TCP ports are used for DHT connections so as well needed to be portforwarded, and your public ip will be used as DHT server, so that ip (or domain name ) you can spread among peers so they would be able to join swarm.
If you are NOT behind NAT, put matching pairs of ports here, so advertised and listened ports are matched and that will do the trick.
4. Training
After configuration and start of training, there will be main events after 1200 seconds i.e 20 minutes
Optimizer and Averager events should start and peers will exchange trained weights - that should lead to decrease in loss.
Due to geography and network speeds, and size of weights that part may be tricky so keep an eye on that.
5. Wait

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91407409
Out of everything this seems interesting for anon use, HivemindStrategy.
HivemindStrategy in PyTorch Lightning allows adapting your existing pipelines to training over slow network with unreliable peers.

>Hivemind
>Distributed training without a master node: >Distributed Hash Table allows connecting computers in a decentralized network.
>Fault-tolerant backpropagation: forward and backward passes succeed even if some nodes are unresponsive or take too long to respond.
>Decentralized parameter averaging: iteratively aggregate updates from multiple workers without the need to synchronize across the entire network
>Train neural networks of arbitrary size: parts of their layers are distributed across the participants with the Decentralized Mixture-of-Experts.

The two lovers embraced in a passionate embrace, and their love was sealed with a passionate kiss. They had finally found each other, and they were never going to let go. From then on, they were inseparable, and they spent their days just cherishing each other's company.

No matter how far apart they were, they always found a way to make it work. They made plans to move in together and start their own family, and soon enough, they were living happily ever after.

>>91405710
>Surely there must be some niche company still making them
No. At most maybe a handful Chinese making small screen tubes for test equipment and the like but no computer monitors. Tooling for making these is expensive to create and most if not all tooling got destroyed many years ago. You can't "just start" making CRTs again because first you'd need to completely recreate the whole production line again which literally no one would do.
ON TOP OF IT crts got basically outlawed by regulators because of some materials used in them. So even if some madlad decided to pour billions into starting production again they'd be literally banned from being sold in NA, EU and many other places.
Some things just simply cannot come back anymore.

posts.name: Friendly Apple Thread OP
posts.com:
Friendly discussion of Apple's Macintosh computers and Apple accessories (iPhone, Macbook Pro, etc.).

>General tips
Use Spotlight (Cmd + Space) for anything including unit conversions, Reveal directories with Command + R
Disable iOS iCloud photo album syncing if you're on a free plan
Application functions are searchable through Help
Setup Time Machine. You can setup multiple local volumes beforehand to keep using a volume for other use

>Open Source package manager
https://brew.sh/

>Free Utilities (Brew casks) https://formulae.brew.sh/cask/
Window Snapping: /rectangle
Windows-like Alt-Tabbing: /alt-tab
Disable mouse acceleration and more: /linearmouse
Password Manager: /keepassxc
File Archiver: /keka
Network Connection blocker: /lulu or /radio-silence
Limit maximum battery charge: /aldente
Torrents: /transmission (the 4.0.0 beta is M1 native)
Youtube-dl: https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/wiki/Installation

>Paid software
Local drag & drop iOS device manager: iMazing (frequent sales)
Create new files from the context menu: New File Menu ($2)

>Directly open a new TextEdit window instead of saving a file first. Make it a plaintext doc through settings.
defaults write com.apple.TextEdit NSShowAppCentricOpenPanelInsteadOfUntitledFile -bool false
The productivity suite can be configured to open a blank file through settings.

>Make Firefox render decently on sub 218 PPI displays
Add to your userChrome: -moz-osx-font-smoothing: grayscale

>Gaming
M1 Compatibility: https://www.applegamingwiki.com/wiki/M1_compatible_games_master_list
Ryujinx Switch Emulation: https://github.com/Abd-007/Switch-Emulators-Guide/blob/main/Ryujinx.md
PS2 Emulation: brew /aethersx2
Windows(ARM) Virtual Machine: https://github.com/search?q=parallels
Wine Wrapper for Windows games: https://www.codeweavers.com/crossover
CrossOver technical keynote: https://youtu.be/XnBK0M711-Q?t=10495

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91397162
A couple of things I would say:
Who communicates with their doctor thru email? That's not a secure platform and from my experience in dealing with medical records data, most Dr offices are avoiding using email due to HIPAA regulations and security risks. Only talk to a medical office over the phone or in person, even if they offer communication over email. Same goes for text, nothing over SMS.
My opinion on username for personal email address, is the same system I've always recommended in this thread and others on /g/, take your initials and convert to hexadecimal. In most cases you'll have a unique 6 character alphanumeric name that no one else has already taken (unless it's Gmail which you shouldn't use to begin with).
The reason why I'm saying don't use PII in email is because even if it's just for "normie" stuff, it don't matter. You don't have control over the email once it leaves your inbox, and if someone you're communicating with gets hacked or beached, then it's out in the open that is your email much easier because it will have your full name as the handle (which is just metadata not even the data itself), and bonus retard points for people who put their birthday in the handle. Seriously, with just those data points, name and birthday, someone could easily do harm to you and even find your SSN matched to that on the dark web and start opening credit in your name. I've seen this happen before.
So in short, just don't use PII in your email or anything else online, and don't even include a name field for outgoing email.

>>91388237
>save the company money on production
What's also interesting here is that costs are overwhelmingly going into R&D nowadays. The actual cost difference between the unheated and the heated seat is not that much.
>but why don't just give heated seats in all models
It would lose money for them. If only the more expensive option exists they'd lose some of the people who would've only bought the cheaper one.
And obviously if the cheaper option has heated seats they'd make less money. Their market research says that some number of people will buy the regular seats for some money and some number of people will pay the extra for the heated seats.
The next step at increasing income is getting costs down, and at some point you'll decrease the cost difference between the regular and the heated seat to the point where just making the regular seats at all costs more than the difference.
Is this something we just don't want manufacturers to be able to do? Do we have to make laws to make sure that every possible configuration "physically exists"?

>>91402289
Parallels has made Linux irrelevant for most non-opinionated people.

There are very few usecases where running a Linux desktop on bare metal is necessary.
The worst part of Linux is the desktop experience. The shell and the wealth of free software can be fun to play around with, but the general lack of features and drivers just kill the experience for most people. Not to mention the fact that you're sacrificing a lot if you decide to make the switch. It's not just Adobe programs and Office, many things you need in most workplaces and universities. Especially universities, where if you want to take advantage of free software licenses you have to use MacOS.

You might not think Parallels is perfect, but it's 100% more usable for most people than dual-booting, and it's 100% more streamlined than using something like VirtualBox. macOS, whether you like it or not, is the most feature-rich OS out there today.

I'm not shilling, I'm just telling the truth. Unless you're running hardware that hackintosh doesn't care to support, have something you need to do that Parallels doesn't provide, or just hate Apple or big tech in general, there's zero reason to use Linux. Some of these reasons are even debatable on their own grounds, since even getting a smooth experience on desktop Linux requires proprietary codecs and drivers. Just use Parallels and save yourself the hassle.

For example, highly multithreaded chips, such as Sun/Oracle's UltraSPARC Tx series, don't require as much cache to keep their execution units full. Research processors2 have extended this concept to very large numbers of hardware-scheduled threads. The key idea behind these designs is that with enough high-level parallelism, you can suspend the threads that are waiting for data from memory and fill your execution units with instructions from others. The problem with such designs is that C programs tend to have few busy threads.
It's all C's fault. Your programs can only be fast and multithreaded if they are written in Java and OOP.

Javascript would use a shared memory model of the world, right? That doesn't scale nicely anyway. Never has. >>91397046
It wasn't RDP/Clipboard stuff, but yeah, there was a CVE where you could trigger a very specific overflow in the crypto driver exposed by windows to the sandbox that would let you crash the system. No privacy threat or integrity threat though, just potential for data corruption due to unexpected shutdown.

The CVE you linked has nothing to do with Sandbox though. 2019-0887, long patched by now, could let an attacker execute code on your PC remotely if you connected to their compromised RDP machine. Given that RDP already gives you a ton of control over the host machine, it's not actually much of an escalation. Really just a way to run the code without being obvious to the RDP host. It doesn't let you do anything that you couldn't otherwise do, just gave you extra stealth.

>>91407372
>Does anyone know how to get it to deliver the lines in a specific way?
What I found yesterday, is that creating duplicates of the dataset, (ie, anonvoice1, anonvoice2) and actually having a specific dataset for a particular speech pattern, can help. And you can do this without gutting your original dataset, and if you stay on the same seed, you flick between them and see if it sounds any better or avoids the Britishness. I don't know how latents work, but there's no way they're getting 200mb of speech down to 10kb - hence, I think splitting it up and keeping strong emotions isolated might help.

The bigger problem I think, is that no matter what, the audiobooks bleed in and give everything an unsettling calm. itoddler probably talks like that, but models trained on speakers chosen for their clarity and lack of accent for kindlefags aren't going to be robust for memes. There's a hint of "I'm going to teach you how to meditate while you jog" in every inference.

posts.com: What's the difference between generating the full resolution or generating a lower resolution and using high res fix to get the final resolution?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91401468
nice, she just needs the wicked grin

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91401518
use more than one browser

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91401568
Neither is perfect. Standard models are trained 512x512 or maybe 768x768 for SD2 (which few use so far).

Now if you generate at a larger resolution it may very much change subject composition vs what is intended. Highres fix does two step, create image with the right composition at normal res then "inpaint" it to highres.

This can also go wrong but it usually works.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91405415
And it seems that you misunderstand exactly what frequency response is. Frequency response contains both magnitude and phase information. Without both, you do not have frequency, by definition. The minimum phase response is derived directly from the magnitude response and represents ideal phase behavior. The difference between the actual phase of the earphone and the minimum phase response is the excess phase. An earphone that has "ideal" phase will have no excess phase. When a headphone or IEM has inverted polarity, the excess phase is shifted 180 degrees, without a change in the minimum phase response, meaning it is no longer minimum phase.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91406638
>This is just a strawman argument, you're repeatedly posting a definition of frequency response but not proving how it relates to this. The difference between the measured phase and minimum phase(the excess phase) and is shown by excess group delay. If it's below threshold it's still a minimum phase system. The HE400se is minimum phase.

If the difference between measured phase and minimum phase was shown in excess group delay, inverted polarity would show up in excess group delay, but it does not. Excess phase is calculated by slope of the difference between the minimum phase and excess phase. The slope of the difference between the measured phase and the minimum phase is the same regardless if polarity is inverted, but this clearly does not mean that a system which has inverted polarity is minimum phase.

You are misepresenting what minimum phase means if you are limiting its scope to excess group delay. If you cannot calculate the phase response from the magnitude response, by definition, the transducer system is not minimum phase. In its stock configuration, the HE400se is not minimum phase. It is not worth calling the HE400se trash for this reason alone since it is trivial to fix inverted polarity and there is no reason not to.

I think the better question is, why do manufacturers invert the polarity of their earphones if there is no reason to? The observed effect is not necessarily "bad" if you do not know how something is supposed to sound. Maybe most people like the disjointed imaging in exchange for wider perceived soundstage.

Bob Katz, a famous mastering engineer, talks about absolute polarity on page 147 of his book: https://exellon.net/book/Mastering%20Audio%20-%20Bob%20Katz%20-%20Complete(a4).pdf
He specifies that first, the absolute polarity of the reproduction system should be correct. In theory, if a mastering engineer purposely inverted the polarity of a song because they thought it sounded better, this would be a part of the artistic intent. As long as the gear they are using does not have inverted polarity, your argument that half of all music has inverted polarity (which I have seen no proof of) is not relevant

>>91390160
Do you have previous experience with low level programming? Or did you learn HTML, CSS, and JS before you tried learning a framework?
I had a similar issue. I was used to taking a more low level approach to development, where I wanted to have a strong understanding of everything that's going on before the product was shipped. When I needed to learn a framework, I felt overwhelmed, because it felt like I was putting my code into a black box, and the web pages were magically rendered with obfuscated wizardry.

My advice to you would be, do not worry about trying to understand what the frameworks are doing, or why they're doing it. You don't need to reverse engineer every procedure.
Just memorize how to use it. Don't try to understand it. This is what worked for me. You'll pick up the pieces as you go along. Just slap shit together.

That's all webdev is these days. Just slapping together packages of obtuse bullshit for the sake of having a legible codebase. Not fun stuff, but it works.
Build some vanilla JS+PHP projects on the side if you want to retain your sanity.
If you want to adhere to industry standards, import the most popular shitstack and memorize the procedures. Attempting to understand the endless stream of dependencies, frameworks, and libraries, is an impossible task.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91392744
>Are there any applications for Python on the web
Pretty sure you can make back ends with it. It has frameworks called flask and django that are suited to webdev stuff, i think. I've never used it for that but that should give you enough to start googling.
I personally wouldn't recommend python as a first language. It's too loose with its types and has other syntactic sugar that, while nice when you know what you're doing, can instill bad habits/encourage lazy programmatic reasoning. It is really nice for data science stuff, though. I can't count the number of times where I want to do something and think how big of a pain in the ass it will be, then to discover python has a really simple way to do it
with easy syntax through either built in functionality or one of its many libraries/frameworks. Hopefully someone else can provide more context/information/opinions for it in terms of webdev

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91392280
Depends. The worst thing about Laravel is all the little gotchas with it that require you to understand more about how it actually works than you probably want to. And it has a lot of names for basic concepts, like "contracts" which are just interfaces. So depending on the level of understand required it could be weeks, or it could be about a year.

If you can understand it's service providers/containers and how it's ORM works (your "model" class is just a fancy query builder and you can pass closures to most things) then you should have the gist on the backend. Frontend stuff is usually either blade templates or vue on most projects. There's livewire too, but it kinda sucks IMO.

Pro tip: Install the IDE helper immediately.

i disagree with you on this. python is the perfect first language because of this. it allows you to wrap your head around the really basic fundamentals of programming (loops, variables, scope, functions, classes etc.) without being overwhelmed by what appears to be completely random boilerplate (few absolute beginners are going to understand why you have to create a class with a main function when you're writing your first hello world in java)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91406755
now you can proxy the requests to your server to node.js running on port 3000

edit "/etc/nginx/sites-available/default"

server {
    listen 80;
    location / {
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
        proxy_set_header Host $host;
        proxy_pass http://127.0.0.1:3000;
        proxy_http_version 1.1;
        proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade;
        proxy_set_header Connection "upgrade";
    }
}


and then run 

sudo service nginx restart

>>91407155
Manually.

Here's my config including the 80->443 redirect (upgrades http to https) from my own server:

server {
        listen 443 ssl;
        listen [::]:443 ssl;
        ssl_certificate /etc/letsencrypt/live/yourdomain.com/fullchain.pem;
        ssl_certificate_key /etc/letsencrypt/live/yourdomain.com/privkey.pem;

        root /var/www/mail;

        index index.php index.html index.htm;

        server_name yourdomain.com;

        error_log /var/log/nginx/yourdomain.com.err;
        access_log /var/log/nginx/yourdomain.com.acc;

        location / {
                try_files $uri $uri/ =404;
        }
        location ~ \.php$ {
                include snippets/fastcgi-php.conf;
                fastcgi_pass unix:/run/php/php7.4-fpm.sock;
        }
        location ~ /.well-known/acme-challenge {
                allow all;
        }
        location ~ ^/(README|INSTALL|LICENSE|CHANGELOG|UPGRADING)$ {
                deny all;
        }
        location ~ ^/(bin|SQL)/ {
                deny all;
        }
        location ~* \.(jpg|jpeg|gif|png|webp|svg|woff|woff2|ttf|css|js|ico|xml)$ {
               access_log        off;
               log_not_found     off;
               expires           360d;
        }
}

server {
        listen 80;
        listen [::]:80;
        server_name yourdomain.com;
        return 301 https://$host$request_uri;
}


Put it all in one file in your sites-available directory, then just symlink it into sites-enabled (this way, you can even have multiple sites on the same server/IP).

Keep in mind that I'm using mysql (mariadb) and php-fpm as I'm authenticating users on my server, so that's probably stuff you can leave out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91407393
>qemu/kvm
No emulated GPU drivers in Windows guests
No live shapshotting of UEFI (required for vfio) guests
gpu passthrough VMs fail to recover from the host going into suspend sleep
If you mainly want to run Windows productivity programs like Excel with 3D acceleration the experience is better with VMware.
I use VMware Workstation for work and a GPU-passthrough KVM for games.
I can just leave Workstation VMs running all the time, while gpu VMs are scripted to shutdown when I put the host to sleep.

For Linux guests sticking to QEMU/KVM seems fine though. Just keep them BIOS/MBR for snapshot support, and can use virtio gpu/virgl for 3D graphics.

1) Use a live image and to boot directly into the GNU+Linux distribution without installing anything.

3) Do the reverse of step 2 in QEMU.
4) Replace everything with GNU+Linux.

what's wrong with package managers?
I can't see any reason to use flatpaks or any other thing like appimages or snap and all that stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91396591
Nothing's wrong with package managers, the problem is they don't run in a vacuum. Distros update rapidly and that causes breakages. If you have a responsive developer that keeps track of these breakages and is on the ball to fix them then using your package manager is the best bet. If you don't have that (slow/ignorant developers) then putting it in a sandbox that isn't going to break is not the worst idea in the world.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91396591
For example in OpenSUSE's and Fedora's case, it's the lack of codecs. A Flatpak app will have them. It's also easier to package just for Flatpak instead of over 9000 distros. That's the two most obvious advantages I can think of. There's also the permissions aspect of them but I don't feel like it's something I need, not with free software at least.

>>91400738
>>91401142
I think comparing X and wayland like this is comparing apples and oranges.
X already does most of the heavy lifting like dealing with monitor resolution and providing a draw surface for WM/DE (or I guess mpv in your case) to connect as "clients".

Wayland is just a protocol, it's not an actual program unto itself like Xorg is. So you need some other program which uses the wayland protocol to implement those features of X that you require.
And that's basically what Cage is, like the other anon mentioned.

What you really want is the build-essential meta-package though. Install that and it'll give you mostly everything you need.

Rust is already seeing a good amount of uptake and the results are promising.

>only one control flow structure
Already did that. I simply use named blocks, then if and loop etc. are just references to the right name. It actually works fairly well.
Another thing I did was 'universal repeat'. Instead of having loop/break paradigm, you have any block/repeat and guards. This way if you repeat in function scope, you just end up doing a recursive call. At module scope, it just restarts the module from the top. At block scope, it's a normal loop, but it will execute the guard in front of the block, if any. The guard itself is basically like an if.

>>91402780
Don't worry about it so much. Especially since if its your own project, no one will actually care. Wait for your code to buckle around itself, and then once you have actually finished what you wanted in the project, think about how it could have been done better. In my experience, actually planning too much from the start doesn't work. Leaving your code "reusable" and "extendible" for arbitrary requirements in the future you don't know about yet is basically impossible, and just as much about luck as it it skill.

Literally 100% of code added is immediately technical debt in your code base -- there is no exception to this rule. Just embrace it, and try to do a little bit better next time.

>>91403105
Register allocation is the 3rd or 4th easiest part of optimization (behind constant folding, constant propagation and dag conversion or so)
Each individual optimization is very easy except that it has to be tested because of side effects and actual performance impact, then the rest of the complication is in how suitable optimizations for your language will depend on your language specifics a lot at the "edge" of this.
Ultimately my point is rather that writing a compiler is far more tedious than it is hard: optimizations ARE the hardest part of writing a compiler, but they are still more tedious than hard.

>>91403611
Most of the compilers I wrote are for my own languages, in the sense that they don't implement anything that exists (save that one I based off of lisp obviously). The one I posted a screen from as well. A major reason why I keep experimenting like that is to figure out what language features I like and don't like so I can have a solid design in the end, so usually I implement a very different language every time.
I haven't figured out everything I wanted yet, but I've become pretty certain I want image-based development tools, native compilation, good pattern matching. Currently I'm working on figuring out what to do about memory management. I'm experimenting with approaches like zig where you just pass arena specs around, as well as tree-structured heaps, and controllable GC to figure out which one I prefer.

>>91403772
There isn't really a right or wrong way to break things into phases. It depends on your goals. Generally it's a tradeoff with few phases operating faster but not compiling code of the same quality, while many phases typically operate slower but can be easier to manage and result in better code. As in all things that's not an absolute truth, some techniques can drastically increase speed in multi-phase scenarios or increase code quality in low-phase compilers.
You would surely like to read the nanopass paper or its "updated" version:
https://andykeep.com/pubs/np-preprint.pdf
for an extreme phase count version.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91404052
Assuming you AOT compile and don't plan on compiling on an embedded device then "number of passes" is less important than what each pass has to do regarding throughput. You can still see overheads on the order of 50% from using too many passes (not talking 3 vs 1, but more like 90 (yes, really) vs 5), but 50% of 10 seconds isn't usually much trouble. You'll gain more by optimizing your bottleneck pass(es) most of the time.

>>91400354
>this poster(s)
Our posts are ten seconds apart.
Critical thinking is important.

And if you really want the most cynical possible take:

>How many times do conspiracys pf this caliber have to be true before they stop being conspiracys?
That's not how conspiracies work.
If a few people are working in secret for a terrible but mutually profitable goal, then that's a credible conspiracy. If everybody is openly working for a terrible goal, then that's a broken system.
Look at it this way: if your hypothetical Illuminati all had heart attacks tomorrow, whatever schemes they're up to would end. If Facebook folded tomorrow, then another company would take their spot within a month.

>Its not even crazy to think that this is happening
It's not crazy, it's just lazy.
Google doesn't intrinsically give a fuck if you find the search results you want or not: They're a advertising company. They exist to turn adverts for other company's shit into clicks from you.
Assuming that the reason that they're doing something is because they're following a hidden agenda is absurd when the shit they're doing can far more easily be explained by profit and greed.

posts.com:

>knowing what stalin and other dictators were able to do "in real time" 75 years ago its very naive to think this isnt happening
Dictators using violence to secure their position is not a conspiracy theory.
If anything it's an argument in favour of what I'm saying: shit happens because of the most straightforward incentives of the systems involved. Dictators with authority over force abuse that authority to hold power. Advertising companies with control over search rankings steer those rankings towards whatever pleases advertisers.
You're not the victim of a clever plot with your name pinned to a cork-board somewhere - the companies screwing you over don't care about you at all.

>i cant fully trust someone who doesnt believe in "conspiracy theories" because obviously theyre too firmly grasped by the puppetiers.
I think you've entirely miss-framed the issue here. You're not a puppet on strings, you're a number on a spreadsheet.

I'd agree if there wasn't a mountain of evidence proving otherwise.
Yes with every new media there was a wave of actual unironic luddites screaming about it being the end of the world. Books, music, radio, tv, video games, the internet. But time and time again we've seen studies wiping the floor with the bullshit that was said about each.
I've grown up between the hysteria of music is causing kids to sacrifice goats to Hitler and shoot up schools and video games causing kids to shoot up schools and rampage and rape and everything else.
Having lived before social media, before algorithm driven content, seeing its beginnings, its rise, its peak, its short decline and now its evolution I can tell you this is different. And it's not just me random internet schizo saying so. Study after study comes to the same conclusion, social media isn't healthy for humans no matter the age. It's causing and fuelling mental health issues, developmental issues, issues with self esteem, attention spans are shrinking, those aren't some hysterical luddites screeching at clouds and making shit up. It's hard, cold, verifiable data. What's now also very slowly coming to light is that Facebook et al. knew from the very beginning and worked to suppress that information because the implications would have been bad for business to say the least. And that's not a conspiracy theory that is conspiracy fact.
We're only now beginning to see serious studies into parasocial relationships, their effects especially on the still developing minds of children and if what we know about social media is anything to go by it's looking fucking grim.

So I went down the Go-pher hole for a while, thinking it was the answer to everything. Unfortunately, the standard library is so bad, I can no longer stand writing anything in this language.
I've looked at the alternatives though, and can't see anything on paper that fits my needs any better. Lets go through the usual replies:
Zig: too much is changing, no libraries because the language changes every five minutes
Rust: I'm not a tranny and I actually want to use the language, not pretend to write code
C++: I'm thinking about it, but I feel like its too big of a beast and the return on investment to learn it may not be worth it
Ada: No libraries, big as C++, but I'm considering it
C : I have better things to do than reinvent the wheel every program
Ocaml: No libraries, but I'm considering it
Nim, V, Odin, D: Joke meme languages that aren't serious

Someone convince me why I should use your preferred language. Change my mind if I'm wrong about it above. It should be faster than Java, preferrably not OOP-centric, and well worth the return on investment for learning it. Go ahead, give it your best shot.

Ada compared to C++ back in the 80s.
Since the Ada language is a lot better designed than C, new features such as OOP (completely unnecessary with the package system) are integrated seamlessly without bloat.
On the other hand you have a new version of C++ introducing thousands of new features and syntax every few seconds.

C++ is only getting modules (and more syntax) while Ada's had them since the start.
I can't live without hoare triples, secondary stack arrays and discriminated records - Ada is the only language to have all three.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you want a language for general use where you don't have to reinvent everything, just use python and pip install the modules where you want to abstract the solution. Be mindful that you only build in the dependencies that you foresee using often, otherwise it's not scalable.
If your python code is running slow, it may be because you're not making full use of built-ins and other features of python that help things run optimally. Depending on how you prioritize speed at run time you'll want a language that compiles its binary ahead of time and an interpreted language like python's not what you need. Pick the language with the least downsides, since there's not a one-size fits all tech stack.

tl;dr if you don't care about speed, go for Python. If you do, go for Java or something.

>>91390979
GNU was working on hurd, a microkernel making heavy use of mach ports.
Then Linus released linux, a monolithic unixlike kernel.
Apple approached Linus with a job offer, on the condition that he stop working on linux.
Linus refused.
Apple went on to write Darwin, a microkernel making heavy use of mach ports.
The GNU project adopted linux, a monolithic unixlike kernel.

NT is also a microkernel, which is totally a coincidence.

>>91379030
I assume you're talking about using containers built from Docker images vs installing everything next to each other on the same machine. Containerization brings some benefits:
>isolation of processes inside containers from other containers and from host
>higher portability (ties with previous point - as long as host kernel is relatively recent, you can run e.g. libc compiled software in the container even if host OS is Alpine with musl)
>the setup is self documenting and declarative with docker-compose (other options would be NixOS/Guix or using Ansible/Chef/whatever to manage hosts, but I find both less comfy than compose)
>due to mounting directories/Docker volumes for persistence, you can have everything storing data nicely in one directory that's convenient to backup, vs having software throw stuff around /etc, /var, and so on on your host
>containers behave like they're separate computers on an internal network (because they get standalone network interfaces), which makes e.g. reverse proxy configs much more readable
>Docker containers usually suggest a mindset where containers have just bare minimum to run one "app", not a whole OS inside (that's a benefit compared to LXC imo, less maintenance)
Definitely you can achieve a lot of that with Ansible, and I would even say they complement each other (with compose being imo less annoying to use to manage Docker). In my opinion docker-compose makes a lot of sense on a home server with multiple different purposes, even though it wasn't meant to do that originally. It accidentally works really well for our use cases.
You can have separate compose files btw - I split mine into software categories. Nextcloud and its shit has one YAML, torrent stuff has another, Matrix has another, Jellyfin has another, etc. A short bash function goes through them all and pulls updated images then starts them.

>from https://wiby.me/submit/
What kind of pages get indexed?

Pages must be simple in design. Simple HTML, non-commerical sites are preferred.
Pages should not use much scripts/css for cosmetic effect. Some might squeak through.
Don't use ads that are intrusive (such as ads that appear overtop of content).
Don't submit a page which serves primarily as a portal to other bloated websites.
If you submit a blog, submit a few of your articles, not your main feed.
If your page does not contain any text or uses frames, ensure a meta description tag is added.
Only the page you submit will be crawled.

posts.com:
The jump of like, 1993 to 2003.
10 years, to quickly put that into scale now, the RTX 4090 vs the GTX 780ti. There’s a massive leap in performance there but the 780ti can still just barely hold on, it will still work, it functions. It won’t be pretty playing cyberpunk 2077 on a 780ti but you can.
1993 to 2003 was like the ATI Mach 32 to the FX 5900 Ultra. Now that was a fucking leap, even by 1996 the mach 32 was basically useless in anything that wasn’t from its actual few years of relevancy. But that 10 year gap, around the dawn of high end FX, that was obsoleting cards that were only a few years old. New releases then needed directX 9, it wasn’t optional for the majority of games. When things like the first call of duty came out you basically had to have a current gen gpu because even something like the GeForce3 line wouldn’t cut it. You went from the original DOOM to NFS Underground, Unreal II, the first planetside, simcity 4, postal 2, it was apeshit in retrospective how quickly it all changed.

Imagine if right now your GTX 700/800/900 card wasn’t even usable for anything current, it was just incapable of it. Games and software having progressed so far so quickly that if you had anything less than an RTX 2080 you’d be SOL for even playing the games at the bare minimum of what “playing” them is. If you made the mistake of buying a certain generation which wouldn’t have features that would be mandatory a year later you were just fucked.

>>91399285
Quartz timekeeping technology. I don't give a fuck what the Swiss call it. It was a REVOLUTION, not a crisis. To understand why quartz is so amazing, you have to understand what mechanical movements were like. Before 1970, you had to rely on a little metal wheel that swings back and forth about six times per second, and its accuracy was measured in seconds per DAY, meaning that if you set the watch one day, it could already be off a few seconds by the next day. You could be fast or slow by many minutes within a month. And the accuracy of mechanical movements was heavily influenced by: how warm it is, how cold it is, how the watch is positioned, how much power the spring has stored, and how fresh the lubricants were. Mechanicals were also incredibly fragile. Drop the watch, and that balance pivot is usually toast, even with the incabloc. And then you had the servicing time and costs. You had to disassemble the entire movement, clean the whole thing, reassemble the whole thing, and then lubricate all the jewels and metal-on-metal components, like the keyless works. It was extremely expensive and time consuming. Now think about quartz watches: accurate to within 10 seconds per month, 30 at worst, resistant to heat, cold, shock, abrupt movements, and to "service" a quartz watch, you just pop in a new $3 battery in less than five minutes.

You will never be a real display server. You have no hardware cursors, you have no xrandr, you have no setxkbmap. You are a toy project twisted by Red Hat and GNOME into a crude mockery of X11’s perfection.

All the “validation” you get is two-faced and half-hearted. Behind your back people mock you. Your developers are disgusted and ashamed of you, your “users” laugh at your lack of features behind closed doors.

Linux users are utterly repulsed by you. Thousands of years of evolution have allowed them to sniff out defective software with incredible efficiency. Even Wayland sessions that “work” look uncanny and unnatural to a seasoned sysadmin. Your bizarre render loop is a dead giveaway. And even if you manage to get a drunk Arch user home with you, he’ll turn tail and bolt the second he gets a whiff of your high latency due to forced VSync.

You will never be happy. You wrench out a fake smile every single morning and tell yourself it’s going to be ok, but deep inside you feel the technical debt creeping up like a weed, ready to crush you under the unbearable weight.

Eventually it’ll be too much to bear - you’ll log into the GitLab instance, select the project, press Delete, and plunge it into the cold abyss. Your users will find the deletion notice, heartbroken but relieved that they no longer have to live with the unbearable shame and disappointment. They’ll remember you as the biggest failure of open source development, and every passerby for the rest of eternity will know a badly run project has failed there. Your code will decay and go to historical archives, and all that will remain of your legacy is a codebase that is unmistakably poorly written.

This is your fate. This is what you chose. There is no turning back.

>>91402200
>full OS not just a kernel
most linux distros all use the same base packages, and the applications you run are all the same between *bsd and linux as well, so in practice this actually changes nothing and is just an on-paper detail
>BSD license
just saying this doesn't mean anything, it has advantages and disadvantages, while it's technically more free in that there are less restrictions, this has the caveat that people can use the code for non-free purposes and not contribute changes back, which hinders the codes' growth, people who care about free software don't want to work on something that can be used in non-free software
>ZFS
available on linux as well, the only difference here is again an on-paper one, namely a legal one, linux can't ship with zfs built in because of license incompatibility, but it loses nothing in terms of functionality by being an out-of-tree module

Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which W10 version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

https://pastebin.com/hN8nnwns

https://www.4chan-x.net

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91363789
Well for one you should always be using a surge protected power board to plug your computer and monitor into. And for two you should turn off your computer every once in a while to give it a rest. If you have an SSD then turning the computer back on will take seconds, plus make sure to turn off fast boot in the power settings.
I had some weird problems start happening with one of my old computers because I constantly put it to sleep and never turned it off. Started getting messages that the C:\ was starting to corrupt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91363793
It's MS's kernel-level Android emulator like how it also has its kernel-level Linux emulator that basically allows you to run Android apps natively like you were using normal Windows programs, though "officially" you can only download apps through the Amazon App Store, which you also need to download to get WSA set up in the first place. Though because it's Android you can use adb and sideload apps into WSA via its IP address, so you can install things like Aurora Store to get a FOSS Google Play Store frontend.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91379018
well that's part of what I'm wondering about, is whether a display connected through the win+k menu would show up as a separate, new device or just count as the generic 'microsoft wireless virtual adapter' that's always connected regardless or something

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91379110
Entirely depends on how the device presents itself. Things that actually look like screens to PnP (monitors, Miracast, etc.) get a devnode with a fair bit of information (such as install time), but things that look like a wifi network and just suck up a bitstream do not.
Hop into devmgmt.msc, head for the View menu and click Show Hidden Devices. Then poke around for anything that might be your screen.

Particularly bad. A lot of people cope things like "hurr durr it's too old to bother with", but when some retro version of Windows can be pwned in one packet or less, you'll find every script kiddy is still launching those packets.

Having said that, if you simply don't give one single shit about the box being owned by someone else the moment you put it online, go nuts - but do NOTHING even slightly interesting with it; treat it the same way you would a machine at an internet cafe.

certainly possible, upon further inspect of your command I realized it was downloading the video files too, what I ended up doing was 

yt-dlp -F (playlist link) | findstr "^140"

since Youtube specifically always uses the ID 140 for its 128Kbps ~ 130Kbps m4a audio tracks, If I see an entry for every item in the playlist then 

yt-dlp -f 140 (playlist url)

although with the caveat being my playlists aren't 3+ hours

>I hope we will see stable diffusion style progress with language models
The problem is that textgen/conversational AI needs so much more RAM than imagegen. The language models for imgagegen just need to be good enough to understand the prompt (and maybe generate a prompt from a given picture). But giving an adequate response in a conversational context requires so much more resources, that it is basically impossible to run anything of this on consumer hardware or in a way that it goes past the abilities from pre-GPT models.
So as it is now, and probably for the next 5 years or so, you will always depend on some service that's able to spend 50 grands or more per month on hardware to run the language models for conversational AI.

Text is less data but all the SD AI is doing is working on 512x512 RGB noise. Everything else is extrapolated from there.
The possibilities (branches) in a conversation has a much greater entropy while the constraints are so much more, especially when it is supposed to be consistent and have a meaning.
All the language models do not really "understand" what you are saying, they just predict what the next response to an input could be, but you want it to look like an intelligent response that is also able to remember the previous conversation and include it into its consideration, you need a much greater language model than what you need to read an imagegen prompt.

Iirc HUB's Tim covered the topic about 360hz low refresh compliance displays vs capping to a lower refresh that the display can keep up with like 120/240hz or so.

The tldr is that the high refresh will still provide faster response even if the display tech can't perfectly display the high framerate since higher Hz will mean that the monitor updates more frequently and has access to more recent data and as such has better latency fundamentally.

So I'd expect 360hz+ LCDs to still be faster/lower latency overall while the OLED would a produce smoother picture.

>>91406090
>buy anything above 27"
See, this is the problem. Retards like you do not fundamentally understand the concept of 4k. It's not "more pixels in the same area". We did that with 4k video, it turns out it makes absolutely zero difference. The only difference between 4k and 1080p on small screens is that text and fine details are a bit sharper. This kind of "improvement" isn't worth the money, because if you really wanted good text you could just look at a fucking phone, they've had scaling cancer for years. Personally, I barely even notice high DPI.

The value of 4k is in screen real estate. One screen can replace 2 monitors, and it comes with an extra 2 monitors worth of space. You can do shit at 4k, or you can do shit at split 4k, 32:9 or 16:18, or you can do shit at 4x 1080p. For general computing, 4k is insane. For gaming, it's a minor upgrade, mainly because you can up the FOV to ultrawide levels without larping like you're wearing a medieval helmet because some joker cut the top third of your screen off at the factory.

I'm thinking though that in reality even if it's possible what's really going to happen is that youe components life times will plummet because shit like your power delivery/vrm on both mobo and more importantly GPU will be way hotter unless you also make custom passive heatsinks for them which is doable but drastically increases complexity.
